The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. div.p: Seasonable Memento's, AND Sober Advice: The former in a very concise Narrative of eight yeares marvellous mercifull Providences, and mans ungratefull Return.
The latter in XVIII. additionall Expedients.

Humbly tendred to the view of all, partakers in the mercies, and parties in the delinquency, BUT Especially to the great Sticklers in the two grand divisions of the Presbyterian and Dissenting Parties.

q.p: He remembred us in our low estate, and rescued us from our oppressors,
Yet they sinned still against him, and provoked God in the wildernesse,
Then there arose a reasoning among them, which of them should be the greatest,
By righteousnesse and judgment the throne and the land is established,
So shalt thou take away the cry of innocent blood from thee, when thou shalt do that which is right in the eyes of the Lord,

div.p: Printed in the Yeere 1647.

div.head: Seasonable Memento's AND Sober Advice, &c.
div.p: LOok a little backward, O ye Brittish Christians, behold and wonder at what the Lord of Hosts your God hath wrought, not onely in the daies of our fathers, in our deliverance from Antichristian darknesse and tyranny, from Spanish plots, and powder-treason, all which never to bee forgotten. But in our daies when we were involved in a condition neere hopelesse, and were brought to the very brinke of desperation; how he raised a religious, noble, and magnanimous spirit in our deer Brethren of renowned Scotland, and how he lead them by the hand through strange difficulties, and those (many) seldome trodden paths; and how hee made them to us a blessing, in procuring to us a Parliament, and how by discoverie of plots and secret crafty Councells, and by overmatching by strong providences the wille and potent adversaries, he catched the wise, even Bishops, and all in their own craftinesse, and over-turned them by their own counsells not a few times, defeating all machinations of Strafford, Canterbury, and their Confederates, of Jermine, and Piercy, and their Complices, of Digby, Byron, Lunsford, of hostile House of Commons visitors, and all that crew, how often since he hath appeared for us (as in the Mount) in the very pinch of our greatest extremities, when our hopes were giving up the ghost.

As at Edge-hill, at Glocester, at Newbery Marsh, and in that march neer Horne Castle, and at Selby, the routing of the Earle of Newcastles formidable Army, the timely helpe by our Scottish Brethren, and taking in Newcastle, at Namptwitch against Irish English, at Cheriton Down, and at Marston Moore, at Newbery again, when we were near as low as any time before: And after all these, when Leicester was lost, and we were againe brought low, when palenesse and fearefull astonishment had seized upon all spirits, and Taunton Dean and the West, were giving up the ghost, and feare was on every side; when the enemy was at the height of his pride, and carnall confidence, and hoped to have over-run us as a flood.

Then, then the Lord arose as in a Baal-Perazim, and brought in salvation to his people, and broke downe those that rose up against them, as a flood of mighty waters, that the sound thereof was heard in all Lands, as 1 Chron. 14.11.17.

Or as when he marched in the angell of his presence before Iosua, and Israel his people, when they entred to possesse the Land, how good was the Lord then in all these unto us, and how greatly to be praised, and truly and faithfully to be served by us? how well might he say to us, as to his people, Exod. 19.4, 5, 6.?
And againe, looke we back, look we backe, O foolish people and unwise, and see how ungratefully we have requited the God of our salvation.

Even when he was most glorious in our deliverance, we then even then instead of consecrating our selves unto his grace, to receive Christ into our hearts, and to walke worthy of him in our lives; instead of provoking each other to love and to good workes in going one before other in the example of a reall Reformation, we then in opposition to the many and great commands of the Gospell, begun to side into parties, to turne Religion into Faction, and band it one against another, even to turn (if possible) each other out of place: bending our endeavours rather to advance a party in Religion, (as if the maine of Religion consisted therein) then to shew forth the vertue, the graces of him who called us out of darknesse, and delivered us out of the night of our affliction, which is indeed the maine of our holy profession, (and of all our holy vowes, made in our distresse) viz. to live by faith, and walke in love, and to take for our helmet the hope of salvation,
(as having had so many experiences) in holinesse, righteousnesse and selfe-deniall, holding forth the word of life (to receive Christ in our hearts, and to walke more worthy of him in our lives, to go one before another in the example of a reall Reformation) in worshipping God in the Spirit, rejoycing in Christ Jesus, and having no confidence in the flesh, consists the all in all of the Christian, whether of the circumcision or the uncircumcision, of the Presbyterian or any waies dissenting judgements: In all which we know we have most sinfully, shamefully, declined, and have frequented most contrary wayes of diffidence in God, and hasty acting in our own strength and way, towards the attaining our desired ends, which he that believes needs not do, yea and have walked in wayes of hatred, anger, envie, clamour, and evill speaking, in pride, oppression, & worldly minded, self-seeking; yea and in much wherein we pretended to be most for God, if we were but searched to the bottome; we are rather acted by a sense of our pre-ingagements, and so indeed serve therein our own selves (yea and in much the Devill) and not our God: we look not towards him with a single eye, nor towards our brethren with an eye of true Christian love, which covereth sinnes, but we look on them through a multiplying glasse, we multiply and discover them to all the world I and that before any Christian proceedings to gaine our brethren: and whereas love seeketh not her owne, nor looketh on her owne things; we look not on the things of others, unlesse on their failings, nor do we seeke others, unlesse their failing; we consider not one another to provoke unto love, and thankfull service to the God of our mercies, but to that wrath, which worketh not the righteousnesse which is of God: declining the Rules of Christ, and way of his peaceable Saints, and giving our selves to bite and devoure one another, until now our sin is ready to become our plague; this Cockatrice egge is ready to bring forth a fiery devouring serpent, and most certainly will (for Gods word is true) if mercy interpose not to the reconciling of our spirits; though in our judgements we should in some things differ still.

Alas, alas, may not Christians and Christians, yea eminent Christians live and enjoy civill interests in common together, because they exactly come not up (or peradventure in some things not done) to each others received opinions and practises in religion, must one party of necessity lay the other under board?
Are ye swolne so big with pride, that the Land and places of trust cannot hold you both, now the good Lord be good to his poore people, will not these sonnes of Zebedee receive our Saviours check?

Take we heed brethren, I beseech you, for the Lords sake, and for his peoples sake, his owne inheritance, that are imbarqued with you; if you sinke the ship, you are likely to answer for all our lives, and ye must give accompt thereof to God, yee shall stand before the Judge, and if ye persist in this contention, it will most certainely sinke us; you see we have enough to doe to saile when all united.

Truly, it is to me a wonder, that the small flocke of Christ is not devoured by the much greater number of greedy Wolves, even when they stand fastest together, its only the miraculous hand of him that dwels among the united in love, and bids them not to feare, that is their securitie: but if they devide and he with-draw, can they be safe? no, reason saith, they cannot, justice saith, they shall not, yea love and mercy consents in it, that so they may be constrained to unite and stand together: but how much lesse can they bee safe, if they shall as a fire consume, or as potters vessells, (for such we are) dash in pieces one another.

O friends, friends, as ye feare God, and love his Son our Lord, who is so tender over his little ones, take heed ye lose not your selves, and these stickling fiery spirits amongst your selves, that would ingage you to call fire from heaven upon their brethren, (but who it would consume they know not;) their Master loves them better then to lose them, for all their heat, and would not have the law of retaliation take place upon them; he hath died for them, as for those, Luke 9.54.

But if ye shall yet be carelesse of your selves and these, yet looke well to it, there are many thousands of peaceable spirits, whose sighs to heaven will make a sad complaint against you; Against you, O ye the great sticklers in these two grand divisions, (that I say not factions) if you shall ingage them in blood, either for the obtaining the Militia, and places of trust in the Kingdome, into the hands of all of either of your two parties; that ye as Kings may rule alone: Or for the obtaining from the Magistrate against those whom holy Paul Phil. 1.7. or other holy Scripture
judges meet to be esteemed Saints, either stripes or frownes in reference to those miscarriages which are to be accompted conscientious failings in their religious conversations in the Churches of Christ.
Or else on the other side, for maintaining heresies, or the obtaining a licentious lewdnesse in Religion, to be incouraged or countenanced by a Law.

I say, if you shall ingage them in blood, or indanger the losse of Religion and liberty, for the obtaining many things lesse principall, although desirable and good, how much more if for such as ought not to be desired?

Take heed, O take heed of division and contention to advance factions, and be intreated in the spirit of Christ, to pursue peace and holinesse, to stand fast in the faith, and follow truth in love, and be ye kinde one to another, tender-hearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christs sake hath forgiven you, Eph. 4.32. And, Put on as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindnesse, humblenesse of minde, meeknesse, long suffering, forbearing one another, and forgiving one another, if any man have a quarrell against any, even as Christ forgave you, so also do ye; and above all these put on charity, which is &c. Col. 3.12. to 15.

Yet O deare Brethren, fellow-Christians, and Countrey-men, if there be any (as I feare there is much) such guilt upon persons amongst us, as that with the persons upon whom it is we may make no peace, justice commanding and calling for execution from; in this I must be silent, or els notwithstanding all those ingagements to love, mercy and forgivenesse, I must cry for justice also, especially (and unquestionably) in the case of blood; if any be known to have the guilt of blood upon them, or if the land be guilty, the person or persons not being known.

The Scriptures are indeed therein expresse, that whosoever (without exception) shall kill any person, the Judge shall slay the murtherer, by man shall his blood bee shed; no satisfaction shall be taken for his life, but he shall surely be put to death, Rom. 35.30, 31. and that the Land cannot be cleansed from the blood that is shed therein, but by the blood of him that shed it, (for blood defileth a Land) Ver. 33.

So that in case the murtherer is knowne, the case is cleare the murtherer must die: and in case that murther is knowne to bee
done in the Land, and the murtherer is not knowne, nor can by diligent inquisition (which must be made) be found out and discovered: yet then are the Elders (the chiefe Governours) in most solemne manner to declare the thing, and protest their own innocency and their ignorance of the murther, that their eye hath not seen it, as Deut. 21.1. to 9. and solemnly to pray that it bee not (by the Lord) imputed unto the Land, and the blood shall bee forgiven them, Ver. 8. and what must then be done in reference to our father James of famous memory, and his sonne, his uncle, and his cozen, with many others, (if Doctor Egleshams printed report be true) but especially in reference to those multitudes of innocent Irish English Christians so barbarously massacred in Ireland.

And further in this our pursuit of peace and good agreement, we also must be mindfull (as ignorant we are not) that there are many persons in each party of our two grand divisions, who according to the extreamenesse of their principles, doe pursue after extreame desires and ends, as either on the one hand lusting after Dominion and Lordship over Gods heritage, endeavour to obtain a carnall power from the Magistrate to excercise that domion carnally, or betraying the authority given by Christ our Lord, unto his Church, not onely engage the Magistrate in things properly appertaining to the Churches cognizance, but refuse to act in Christs name and by his authority, untill (or any further then) the Magistrate will by his power direct them in and secure them for, so doing; or else on the other hand to tie up the hand of the Magistrate from punishing notorious evill doers against Rom. 13. if not, which is worse, to engage him by a declared generall toleration to countenance and incourage heresies and blasphemies by a Law.

Neither of which can have their desires granted without an extreamer damage and disadvantage to Religion and the publike interest, whom our endeavours therefore must be rather to moderate and pacifie, then to satisfie in their desires; onely the wise according to sobriety, can have their desires (as consisting with Gods honour and publike safety) satisfied and fulfilled. And peradventure for peace sake, something of what is truly desirable must for present be forborne, as not yet to bee obtained, without a greater over-ballancing, evill coming along with it.

For the avoyding of which evils and extreams, on the Right hand, and on the left, and obtaining a greatly desired healing and setling of our present distempers, and prevention of that destruction which now lyeth at the very door: These Additional expedients are humbly tendred to Consideration.

First, that a day of general humiliation may be speedily obtained wherein in special to humble our selves for our miscarriages in the former references, and to wrastle with God for Grace and mercy in this business.

2. That the Solemn Covenant truly and candidly understood should be Religiously and inviolably observed. That the Word of God, and not humane example, nor Magisterial authority or countenance, may in our Church Reformation be especially eyed.

3. And that we in tithing of Mint and Annise, in our eager pursuite of uniformity in circumstantials, indanger not the losing of unity of spirit and the lively exercise of faith, and love, the great duties of a Christian, and so be found contrariant to sound Doctrine, and the power of godliness: But that we make it our Great design to live together in faith and love, that the Lord may delight to dwel among us.

4. And although we be not all of one size, some higher and stronger, some weaker, and less necessary — that we covering sins, and being ambitious of giving honor, may give more abundant honor to that part which lacketh, whether Presbyterian or dissenting, that there be no schism in the body 1 Cor. 12.25. And yet by all due Christian means, endeavour to suppress all superstition, Heresie, Prophaness, and whatsoever is found contrary to sound Doctrine, and the power of godlsness, That the Lord may be one, and his name one.
5. That in the name of Christ, and by his Authority all worldly Institutions and officers, as Prelates &c. in the Church and Kingdom of Jesus Christ may be expulsed and suppressed.
6 That justice may be done, both to King and people, and all in their just Rights defended in the preservation and defence of true Religion and Liberty.

7. That Justice be done upon Incendiaries, Dividers of Church or • tate into factions and parties among the people; and in particular and special upon the wilful opposers and hinderers of the peace and union of, and between the three Kingdoms.

8. That a quest of inquity be speedily appointed for searching ofts the Achans, especially men of blood that trouble our Israel, and procure the curse, or the continuance thereof: that Justice may proceed according to Covenant and the curse may cease. And that: any thing hard or difficult herein appear, The assembly of Divine be therein consulted.

That what guilt of innocent blood is found to lie upon us, the authors whereof cannot be found (or not dealt with according to common Iustice) — That in reference thereunto though we are not to kil the red cow, as Deut. 21. yet to do that which is equivalent thereunto— viz. solemnly to humble our selves before the Lord, and expiate the sin by faithful prayer for pardon in the blood of Christ, That the sin may be forgiven us, as Deut. 21.8.

9. That in pursuance of Unity, Peace and good Agreement in the things of Religion (as there is already appointed fit persons to treat for the settling of the general and great affairs of the Kingdom) so also in particular and special, That (if it be not already done as was reported) some of the most eminently approved godly, impartial, and in this difference most disingaged either of the Parliament or Ministry, or others, whom the Parliament shal think fit, be appointed speedily to consider of some expedients tending thereunto.

10. That things may therein be so stated, that none fearing God and conscientiously walking in his word and worship (or according to Scripture grounds to be accounted for such; viz. visible Saints not liable to Church censure, but capable of Christian Communion) may not be therein molested or disheartned, but receive all due incouragement and countenance both from each other, and from the Magistracy of the Kingdom, yet so as not owning one anothers errors or miscarriages, but walking together in that whereunto they have already attained.

11. and that in setling the other great affairs of the Kingdom care may be taken so to state things with impartial respect unto the wel-deserving of either Judgment, that none that are wel-affected to the publick Interest may be deprived of their just civil Rights and Priviledges, nor any that have wel deserved of the Kingdom may lose their due honor and reward, because dissenting something in opinion.

12. That in the time of the Treaty for the removing and preventing of suspitions and jealousies on either side; That all those Commanders
formerly of the Army at the time of the displeasing Vote passed against their Petition, as wel as the old Militia of the City of London, except such of both against whom material objections of unfaithfulness or other palpable gross absurdities can be made, may be set in statis quo prius. Or if the City cannot yeeld that the old Militia shal take place with the exceptions as above, that then the City beg leave of the Parliament to choose a new with promise and assurance to choose such as shal please the Parliament and remove Jealousies, (the City soldiery in the interim to be inabled to act under any one, two or three for common quiet, and the Army to forbear advancing) which course would also unite the City. And the places of trust in the City & Kingdom being for the present impartialy distributed amongst the able, wel-deserving, best-esteemed, and most moderate of both parties, would remove jealousies and unite both City and Kingdom.

13. That Immediatly after such setling the Army and Militia, The Eleven Members be speedily called to tryal, or else (urgency of occasions not permitting) to give security to answer when called and in the mean time to injoy their places and Priviledges of Sitting and Voting in Parliament.
14. That the Presbyterian Government in the most Spiritual perfection and freedom thereof may be incouraged.

15. That (the Law of premunire being taken away) they may have liberty to act according to the Word of God, and Cannons of the Great Doctor and Lawgiver, Christ Jesus; and may be admonished (as the Britains by the Bishop of Rome, to search there for Rules and Laws to govern the Churches of Christ, And may not be bound up by humane Restrictions.

16. That some course be thought on to inflict severe penalties upon railing Rabshekaes, that in such sordid and scurrilous language or writings (as is now common) do or shal vilifie the said Government or Ministry thereof, or the Ministry of the Kingdom in general, or any religious way, or persons in reference to such way, or any religious Societies whatsoever, especially if not before declared against by the then present Government of the Kingdom.

17. But let all bitterness, and anger, and wrath, and clamour, and evil speaking bee (commanded to be) put away (from all Christians in this Kingdom) with all malice, Eph. 4.31. Seeing Michael
the Archangel, when contending with the Devil &c. durst not bring against him a railing accusation, but said, The Lord rebuke thee, Iude 9.
18. And let the peace of God rule in your hearts, to the which also ye are called in one body; and be ye thankeful, Col. 3.15.
Fall not out by the way, Gen. 45.24.
Have peace one with another, Marke 9.5.
By this shal all men know that you are my Disciples, if ye have love one to another, John 13.34, 35.
He that loveth not his brother abideth in death, 1 Iohn 3.14.
Love envieth not, boasteth not it self, is not puffed up; love seeketh nother own things, thinketh no evil, — love beleeveth all things, hopeth all things, indureth all things. 1 Cor. 13.4.5.7.
